clinical_study.brief_title: Bystander Helping Behaviour for Myocardial Infarction Following First Aid Training
clinical_study.official_title: Bystander Helping Behaviour for Acute Myocardial Infarction Following a First Aid Training Programme That Draws Attention to the Barriers to Providing Help - Protocol for a Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: The objective of this study is to measure the effect of an innovative training programme on the help seeking behaviour and helping rates of bystanders in medical emergencies.

detailed_description.textblock:
A systematic review on the effects of first aid training concluded that training must also include ways to overcome obstacles to bystander intervention. This could lead to better help and higher helping rates in medical emergencies.
The objective of this paper is to measure the effect of an innovative training programme on the help seeking behaviour and helping rates of bystanders in medical emergencies. We chose to test the helping behaviour for acute myocardial infarction because it is an important cause of mortality and invalidity. While the victim is urgently in need of help, delay in seeking professional help is an important problem.

primary_outcome.measure: Delay time for seeking help during deception experiment
primary_outcome.time_frame: within 4 weeks after the control or intervention training
primary_outcome.description: Time to seeking help was measured between the simulated patient grabbing the heart and the study participant opening the door to get help.

secondary_outcome.measure: Rate of helping during deception experiment
secondary_outcome.time_frame: within 4 weeks after control or intervention training
secondary_outcome.description: This refers to the number of participants that assessed the victim, or asked for help, or provided direct help to the victim during the test.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: within 15 minutes after experimental or control intervention
secondary_outcome.description: scores on 6 questions related to helping behaviour barriers with the following structure: " I will do x (action) even if y (barrier)"
This indicates how shocking the study participants found the simulated emergency situation
Indication of how study participants feel after being told about the deception.
Indication of how credible study participants found the simulated emergency situation

arm_group.description: The helping behaviour training is given after 24 hours first aid training and aims to sensitise participants towards a helping reaction and teach participants how to deal with barriers to helping
This group receives training in first aid only without training in helping behaviour.

intervention.description: The objective of the helping behaviour curriculum is to sensitise participants to develop a helping reaction, and to teach participants how to deal with barriers to helping. The helping behaviour curriculum is being taught in 2hours.
Two hours training on first aid for alcohol and drug incidents

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Course participants that are 18 years or older
Exclusion Criteria:
- Course participants that are younger than 18 years
- Health care students
- Health care professionals
